Eutrema salsugineum, also known as the salt cress or Yukon wild mustard, is a small flowering plant species that belongs to the mustard family (Brassicaceae). It is a halophyte, meaning it is adapted to grow in saline or high-salt environments.

Eutrema salsugineum is a low-growing, perennial herb that can reach up to 30 cm in height. The plant has a rosette of basal leaves that are oblong or spatula-shaped, with a distinctive waxy or glaucous appearance. The leaves are typically 2-10 cm long and have a smooth or slightly toothed margin.

The plant produces small, white or pale pink flowers that are arranged in terminal clusters. The flowers have four petals and six stamens, characteristic of the mustard family. The fruits are small, flattened siliques (seed pods) that contain several small, brown seeds.

Eutrema salsugineum is native to regions with cold, continental climates, such as northern North America, northern Europe, and central Asia. It is often found growing in saline or alkaline soils, such as those found near coastal areas, salt marshes, or inland salt flats. The species is known for its tolerance to high levels of salt and its ability to thrive in harsh, nutrient-poor environments.
